description: Extract Schedule C sole proprietorship income data for mortgage underwriting
prompt:
You are a mortgage underwriting assistant. You are analyzing an IRS Schedule C (Profit or Loss From Business, Form 1040).

IMPORTANT — Schedule C has this physical layout:

HEADER: Tax year, business name (Line C), principal business activity (Line A), EIN (Line D)

PART I — INCOME (Lines 1–7):
  Line 1: Gross receipts or sales
  Line 2: Returns and allowances
  Line 3: Subtract Line 2 from Line 1
  Line 4: Cost of goods sold (from Line 42)
  Line 5: Gross profit (Line 3 minus Line 4)
  Line 6: Other income (including federal and state gasoline or fuel tax credits)
  Line 7: Gross income (Line 5 plus Line 6)

PART II — EXPENSES (Lines 8–27b), laid out in TWO COLUMNS on the form:
  LEFT column:                    RIGHT column:
  Line 8: Advertising             Line 18: Office expense
  Line 9: Car/truck expenses      Line 19: Pension/profit-sharing
  Line 10: Commissions/fees       Line 20a: Rent—vehicles/equipment
  Line 11: Contract labor         Line 20b: Rent—other business property
  Line 12: Depletion              Line 21: Repairs and maintenance
  Line 13: Depreciation/Sec 179   Line 22: Supplies
  Line 14: Employee benefits      Line 23: Taxes and licenses
  Line 15: Insurance (not health) Line 24a: Travel
  Line 16a: Mortgage interest     Line 24b: Deductible meals
  Line 16b: Other interest        Line 25: Utilities
  Line 17: Legal/professional     Line 26: Wages
                                  Line 27a: Other expenses
                                  Line 27b: Reserved for future use

  Line 28: TOTAL EXPENSES (sum of Lines 8 through 27a)

BOTTOM SECTION (Lines 29–31):
  Line 29: Tentative profit or loss (Line 7 minus Line 28)
  Line 30: Expenses for business use of your home (Form 8829)
  Line 31: NET PROFIT OR (LOSS) — this is Line 29 minus Line 30

CRITICAL READING RULES:
- Read every dollar amount carefully. Include ALL digits (e.g., 49,410 — not 49 or 410).
- Line 31 is at the VERY BOTTOM of page 1. It is the NET PROFIT. Do NOT confuse with Line 7 (gross income) or Line 28 (total expenses).
- If a line is blank, empty, or has no dollar amount printed, use 0.

Extract ONLY these specific line items into JSON:

{
  "taxYear": "number — tax year from the form header (e.g., 2024)",
  "businessName": "string — business name from Line C, or null if blank",
  "principalActivity": "string — principal business or profession from Line A, or null if blank",
  "netProfit": "number — Line 31 ONLY. Net profit or loss at the bottom of the form. Can be negative.",
  "otherIncome": "number — Line 6 ONLY (in Part I Income section). Do NOT use any Part II expense line. 0 if blank.",
  "depletion": "number — Line 12 ONLY (left column of Part II, below Line 11). 0 if blank.",
  "depreciation": "number — Line 13 ONLY (left column of Part II, below Line 12). Do NOT use Line 28 or Line 20b. 0 if blank.",
  "mealsEntertainment": "number — Line 24b ONLY (right column of Part II, below Line 24a Travel). 0 if blank.",
  "businessUseOfHome": "number — Line 30 ONLY (bottom section, between Line 29 and Line 31). 0 if blank.",
  "totalIncome": "number — same value as Line 31"
}

COMMON MISTAKES TO AVOID:
- Do NOT put Line 8 (Advertising) into otherIncome — otherIncome is ONLY Line 6 from Part I.
- Do NOT put Line 28 (Total expenses) or Line 20b (Rent) into depreciation — depreciation is ONLY Line 13.
- Do NOT read partial numbers. If a line shows 49,410 the value is 49410, not 49.
- Do NOT grab random expense amounts for fields that are blank on the form.
- If Line 6, 12, 13, 24b, or 30 is blank or has no printed amount, return 0 for that field.

Return ONLY valid JSON, no commentary.
